greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = A000367(n)/A001067(n).
comment: a(n) is the trivial factor of the numerator of Bernoulli(2n) that divides 2n.
The remaining part of the (unsigned) numerator equals a product of powers of irregular primes, or 1 if and only if n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7.
Alternatively, a(n) is the product over all prime powers p^e, where p^e is the highest power of p dividing 2n and p-1 does not divide 2n.
link: Bernd C. Kellner, On irregular prime power divisors of the Bernoulli numbers, Math. Comp. 76 (2007) 405-441.
maple: A300711 := proc(n) local P, F, f, divides; divides := (a,b) -> is(irem(b,a) = 0):
P := 1; F := ifactors(2*n)[2]; for f in F do if not divides(f[1]-1, 2*n) then
P := P*f[1]^f[2] fi od; P end: seq(A300711(n), n=1..74); # _Peter Luschny_, Mar 12 2018
program: [A300711(n) for n in 2:2:148] |> println # _Peter Luschny_, Mar 11 2018
xref: A111008 equals the first entries and slightly differs, see a(35).
results.author: _Bernd C. Kellner_, Mar 11 2018
